Copper is essential for cell growth and development as a cofactor of cytochrome c oxidase, copper,zinc-dependent superoxide dismutase, ceruloplasmin, lysyl oxidase, and other important metabolic enzymes. However, abnormally elevated copper disrupts cell metabolism, presumably by stimulating the production of reactive oxygen species. Toxic effects of copper are evident in patients with Wilson's disease, a genetic disorder characterized by accumulation of copper in tissues and severe hepatic and neurological problems (1Loudianos G. Gitlin J.D. Semin. Liver Dis. 2000; 20: 353-364Crossref PubMed Scopus (146) Google Scholar). To regulate the intracellular copper concentration, cells have developed a sophisticated network of copper-trafficking proteins that includes the copper-transporting ATPases and metallochaperones (2Harrison M.D. Jones C.E. Solioz M. Dameron C.T. Trends Biochem. Sci. 2000; 25: 29-32Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (225) Google Scholar, 3O'Halloran T.V. Culotta V.C. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 25057-25060Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (669) Google Scholar, 4Lutsenko S. Efremov R.G. Tsivkovskii R. Walker J.M. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 2002; 34: 351-362Crossref PubMed Scopus (60) Google Scholar). The Wilson's disease protein (WNDP) 1The abbreviations used are: WNDP Wilson's disease protein; BCA, bicinchoninic acid; BCS, bathocuproine disulfonate; CPM, 7-diethylamino-3-(4′-maleimidylphenyl)-4-methylcoumarin; XAS, X-ray absorption spectroscopy; EXAFS, extended X-ray absorption fine structure; Tricine, N-[2-hydroxy-1,1-bis(hydroxymethyl)ethyl]glycine; MBS, metal-binding site; CAPS, 3-(cyclohexylamino)propanesulfonic acid. is a copper-transporting P-type ATPase that plays a key role in copper distribution in the liver, kidney, and the brain. WNDP utilizes the energy of ATP hydrolysis to transport the metal into the secretory pathway for incorporation into such copper-dependent enzymes as ceruloplasmin and to export excess copper from the cell (5Lutsenko S. Petris M.J. J. Membr. Biol. 2003; 191: 1-12Crossref PubMed Scopus (176) Google Scholar). WNDP and other eucaryotic copper-ATPases are unique among the P-type ATPases because they do not bind copper directly from the cytosol (where the amounts of free copper are extremely low (6Rae T.D. Schmidt P.J. Pufahl R.A. Culotta V.C. O'Halloran T.V. Science. 1999; 284: 805-808Crossref PubMed Scopus (1379) Google Scholar)) but receive the metal ion from a small cytosolic protein called a metallochaperone through direct protein-protein interactions (7Lockhart P.J. Mercer J.F. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2000; 1490: 11-20Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar, 8Larin D. Mekios C. Das K. Ross B. Yang A.S. Gilliam T.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 28497-28504Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (150) Google Scholar, 9Walker J.M. Tsivkovskii R. Lutsenko S. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 27953-27959Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar, 10Pufahl R.A. Singer C.P. Peariso K.L. Lin S.J. Schmidt P.J. Fahrni C.J. Culotta V.C. Penner-Hahn J.E. O'Halloran T.V. Science. 1997; 278: 853-856Crossref PubMed Scopus (595) Google Scholar). Atox1 (previously known as HAH1) serves as a metallochaperone for WNDP. Several mutations in WNDP originally found in Wilson's disease patients were shown to disrupt the Atox1-WNDP interaction (11Hamza I. Schaefer M. Klomp L.W. Gitlin J.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 13363-13368Crossref PubMed Scopus (242) Google Scholar), suggesting that Atox1 is required for WNDP function. In agreement with this prediction, we demonstrated that Atox1 directly transfers copper to WNDP and that copper delivery results in stimulation of the WNDP catalytic activity (9Walker J.M. Tsivkovskii R. Lutsenko S. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 27953-27959Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar). Conversely, apoAtox1 can strip copper from WNDP, leading to inhibition of WNDP (9Walker J.M. Tsivkovskii R. Lutsenko S. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 27953-27959Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar). Therefore, Atox1 can regulate the functional activity of WNDP by modulating the amount of copper bound to the protein. Although the role of Atox1 in copper delivery to WNDP seems clear, the molecular details of this intriguing process remain uncertain. WNDP contains a large N-terminal domain (N-WNDP) with six metal binding subdomains (MBS) that have homologous sequences (Fig. 1) and a very similar βαββαβ fold (12Jones C.E. Daly N.L. Cobine P.A. Craik D.J. Dameron C.T. J. Struct. Biol. 2003; 143: 209-218Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar, 13Gitschier J. Moffat B. Reilly D. Wood W.I. Fairbrother W.J. Nat. Struct. Biol. 1998; 5: 47-54Crossref PubMed Scopus (212) Google Scholar). Each MBS includes a conserved GMXCXXC sequence, which is situated in the exposed loop. It has been shown that N-WNDP binds up to six Cu+ ions and that copper is coordinated by the two cysteines of the GMXCXXC sequence (14Lutsenko S. Petrukhin K. Cooper M.J. Gilliam C.T. Kaplan J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 18939-18944Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (214) Google Scholar, 15DiDonato M. Narindrasorasak S. Forbes J.R. Cox D.W. Sarkar B. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 33279-33282Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (139) Google Scholar, 16DiDonato M. Hsu H.F. Narindrasorasak S. Que Jr., L. Sarkar B. Biochemistry. 2000; 39: 1890-1896Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar). Atox1 contains a similar copper-binding motif, MXCXXC (Fig. 1), and binds one Cu+ per protein (17Hung I.H. Casareno R.L. Labesse G. Mathews F.S. Gitlin J.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 1749-1754Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (130) Google Scholar, 18Ralle M. Lutsenko S. Blackburn N.J. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 23163-23170Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (104) Google Scholar). Interestingly, Atox1 has the same overall fold as the individual copper binding subdomains of N-WNDP (19Wernimont A.K. Huffman D.L. Lamb A.L. O'Halloran T.V. Rosenzweig A.C. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2000; 7: 766-771Crossref PubMed Scopus (358) Google Scholar). This similarity in structure and the presence of complimentary charges at the surface of Atox1 and some of the N-terminal MBS of the copper-transporting ATPases led to the suggestion that Atox1 docks to MBS and transfers copper via ligand exchange (13Gitschier J. Moffat B. Reilly D. Wood W.I. Fairbrother W.J. Nat. Struct. Biol. 1998; 5: 47-54Crossref PubMed Scopus (212) Google Scholar, 19Wernimont A.K. Huffman D.L. Lamb A.L. O'Halloran T.V. Rosenzweig A.C. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2000; 7: 766-771Crossref PubMed Scopus (358) Google Scholar, 20Arnesano F. Banci L. Bertini I. Ciofi-Baffoni S. Molteni E. Huffman D.L. O'Halloran T.V. Genome Res. 2002; 12: 255-271Crossref PubMed Scopus (234) Google Scholar). The crystallographic structure of Atox1, in which one copper bridges two Atox1 monomers, provides an attractive model for such a copper-transfer intermediate (19Wernimont A.K. Huffman D.L. Lamb A.L. O'Halloran T.V. Rosenzweig A.C. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2000; 7: 766-771Crossref PubMed Scopus (358) Google Scholar). Despite considerable progress in the structural characterization of Atox1 and individual MBSs, it is still unknown how copper migrates within N-WNDP after transfer from Atox1. In fact, even the first step of this process is poorly understood. For example, we do not know whether Atox1 docks randomly to any MBS and transfers copper with equal efficiency or if there is a specific and unique entry pathway in the N-WNDP for copper. It is also unclear what happens after copper is transferred to N-WNDP. Previous studies demonstrated that although six MBS of N-WNDP are structurally similar, their functions are distinct. MBS5 and MBS6 are important for copper delivery to the intramembrane copper-binding site(s) (21Forbes J.R. Hsi G. Cox D.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 12408-12413Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar) and appear to control the affinity of these sites for the metal (22Huster D. Lutsenko S. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 32212-32218Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar). In contrast, MBS 1-4 do not affect the affinity of the intramembrane sites but may regulate the access of copper to these sites and modulate the enzyme turnover (22Huster D. Lutsenko S. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 32212-32218Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar). Interestingly, the fragment of N-WNDP including MBS1-4, but not the MBS5- and MBS6-containing fragment, was shown to interact with the copper-bound Atox1 (8Larin D. Mekios C. Das K. Ross B. Yang A.S. Gilliam T.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 28497-28504Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (150) Google Scholar). Thus, taken together the experimental data suggest that copper translocation through N-WNDP toward the intramembrane portion is likely to involve several MBS and represent a multistep process. To better understand the molecular mechanism of this process, here we characterized the consequences of the Atox1-mediated transfer of a single copper ion to WNDP. We demonstrate that Atox1 selectively delivers copper to MBS2 and that this step is essential for further migration of copper to the intramembrane copper-binding sites of WNDP. Recombinant Proteins—Expression and purification of Atox1 were carried out using a published protocol (9Walker J.M. Tsivkovskii R. Lutsenko S. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 27953-27959Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar). Briefly, the recombinant Atox1 was expressed in Escherichia coli as an intein fusion and purified from a soluble fraction of cell lysate using affinity chromatography on chitin beads (New England Biolabs). After washes with 25 mm Na2HPO4, 150 mm NaCl, pH 7.5 (Buffer A), Atox1 was cleaved from the fusion protein and eluted from the resin by incubation with 50 mm dithiothreitol in 25 mm Na2HPO4, 150 mm NaCl, pH 8.15. The protein was then dialyzed into buffer A and used for copper binding and transfer experiments. The copper-bound form of Atox1 (Cu+-Atox1) was generated by incubation of apoAtox1 with equimolar amount of a copper-glutathione complex as described (9Walker J.M. Tsivkovskii R. Lutsenko S. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 27953-27959Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar) and dialyzed into buffer A. The protein concentration of Cu+-Atox1 was determined by the Bradford assay (23Bradford M.M. Anal. Biochem. 1976; 72: 248-254Crossref PubMed Scopus (217544) Google Scholar), and the amount of bound copper was measured using a bicinchoninic acid (BCA) assay (24Brenner A.J. Harris E.D. Anal. Biochem. 1995; 226: 80-84Crossref PubMed Scopus (171) Google Scholar) or atomic absorption spectroscopy (Shimadzu AA-6650G). The typical stoichiometry of the Cu+-Atox1 complex was 0.8-0.95 copper per protein; the reducing state of copper was verified by electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy. The expression and purification of the N-WNDP-maltose-binding protein fusion (abbreviated here as N-WNDP for simplicity) was described previously (14Lutsenko S. Petrukhin K. Cooper M.J. Gilliam C.T. Kaplan J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 18939-18944Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (214) Google Scholar). Briefly, to maintain solubility, the recombinant N-WNDP fusion was co-expressed with thioredoxin in E. coli and purified using affinity chromatography on amylose resin (New England Biolabs). N-WNDP was washed with buffer A and eluted from the resin with buffer A containing 10 mm maltose. To produce the recombinant metal binding subdomain 2 (MBS2, residues 141-212 of WNDP), the corresponding segment of the ATP7B cDNA was amplified using the following primers: forward, 5′-CATATGCAGGAGGCTGTGGTC-3′; reverse, 5′-GTCGACTTAGCTCTTGATGGCAGC-3′. The primers were designed such that 5′ NdeI and 3′ SalI restriction sites were incorporated into the MBS2 PCR product. The PCR fragment was cloned into the pTYB12 IMPACT expression vector (New England Biolabs) to produce the pTYB12-MBS2 expression plasmid, and the sequence fidelity was verified by automated DNA sequencing. E. coli ER2566 cells were transformed with the pTYB12-MBS2-intein plasmid, and the expression of the MBS2 fusion was induced by isopropyl-β-d-thiogalactopyranoside added to a final concentration of 500 μm at 25 °C for 20 h. The MBS2 was purified from the soluble fraction using the protocol described above for Atox1 and dialyzed into buffer A. The copper-bound form of MBS2 was generated by incubation of apoMBS2 with equimolar amounts of a copper-glutathione complex and dialyzed into 20 mm Na2HPO4, 150 mm NaCl, pH 7.5, for copper competition experiments. Copper Transfer Experiments—Before copper transfer experiments, the purified N-WNDP bound to amylose resin was reduced by incubating with 100 μm Tris(2-carboxyethyl)phosphine hydrochloride (Sigma) for 10 min. After a wash with 3 resin volumes of buffer A, apoAtox1 or Cu+-Atox1 was added and incubated with N-WNDP for 10 min. To remove the chaperone, the resin was washed extensively with 10 volumes of buffer A, and N-WNDP was eluted with buffer A containing 10 mm maltose. The protein concentration and the copper stoichiometry were measured in the eluted samples of N-WNDP as described above. For copper binding in the absence of Atox1, N-WNDP was incubated with increasing concentrations of CuCl2 (Sigma) dissolved in buffer A containing freshly prepared 200 μm ascorbate (Fisher). Under these conditions all copper is present in the reduced form (our data). The time of incubation and subsequent washes and elution steps were the same as for experiments with Cu+-Atox1. Chemical Labeling and Proteolysis of N-WNDP—273 pmol (30 μg) of apo-N-WNDP, N-WNDP preincubated with apoAtox1, or N-WNDP with one copper transferred from Atox1 were incubated with a 50-fold molar excess of the cysteine-directed reagent 7-diethylamino-3-(4′-maleimidylphenyl)-4-methylcoumarin (CPM, Molecular Probes) for 2.5 min in the dark at room temperature. The reaction was quenched with a 10-fold molar excess of β-mercaptoethanol over CPM. The fluorescently labeled N-WNDPs were then proteolyzed with the l-1-tosylamido-2-phenylethyl chloromethyl ketone-treated bovine pancreas trypsin (Sigma) added to protein at a 1:2000 (w/w) ratio for 3 h at room temperature; the reaction was stopped with the addition of 2 mm 4-(2-aminoethyl)benzenesulfonyl fluoride (ICN Biomedicals) (under these conditions the maltose-binding protein part of the N-WNDP fusion protein is not proteolyzed, but the N-WNDP portion of the fusion is fragmented). The proteolyzed N-WNDP fragments were separated on a 15% Tris-Tricine gel (25Schagger H. von Jagow G. Anal. Biochem. 1987; 166: 368-379Crossref PubMed Scopus (10505) Google Scholar), and the separation of the CPM-labeled peptides was monitored under UV light using a Gel-Doc system (Bio-Rad). The protein fragments were then either stained with Coomassie R250 or transferred to polyvinylidene difluoride membrane (Millipore) at 185 mA for 40 min in 10% methanol, 10 mm CAPS, pH 11.0, and stained with Coomassie R250. The fluorescent and Coomassie-stained patterns of the peptides from the apo- and copper-bound N-WNDP were compared. For N-terminal sequence analysis, the membrane was rinsed with water and dried; the bands were cut out and submitted to the sequencing facility. Surface labeling of N-WNDP was performed by incubating 273 pmol of apo-N-WNDP with 0, 1, and 2 mol equivalent of CPM in buffer A. The reaction was quenched with β-mercaptoethanol. The labeled samples were then digested with trypsin and analyzed by Tris-Tricine gel electrophoresis as described above. Comparison of the Copper Binding Characteristics of MBS2 and Atox1 Using Competition with the Copper Chelator BCA—Copper-bound Cu+-Atox1 and Cu+-MBS2 were diluted with 20 mm NaH2PO4, 150 mm NaCl, pH 7.5, buffer containing freshly prepared 40 μm ascorbate to obtain a 7.5 μm concentration of the copper-containing complex. The proteins were then incubated with increasing concentrations of BCA for 10 min. The formation of the BCA-Cu(I) complex was monitored spectrophotometrically at 562 nm with a Beckman DU 640B spectrophotometer. A solution containing 7.5 μm CuCl2, 40 μm ascorbate, 20 mm NaH2PO4, 150 mm NaCl, pH 7.5, was used as a control. X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy (XAS) Data Collection and Analysis—For the XAS experiments the reconstitution of MBS2 with copper was performed in an inert atmosphere using an anaerobic chamber to prevent the oxidation of cysteine residues. Before metal reconstitution, a 10-fold molar excess of dithiothreitol was added to MBS2 on ice, and the mixture was incubated for 10 min. The protein was then dialyzed overnight under argon into a buffer containing 50 mm HEPES and 10% acetonitrile at pH 7.5. Copper was added as a tetra-acetonitrile complex, [(CH3CN)4Cu(I)]PF6, dissolved in the same buffer to an equimolar ratio to the protein. The Cu+-MBS2 was then dialyzed in successive steps of 12 h each against 50 mm HEPES, 10% acetonitrile, pH 7.5; 50 mm HEPES, 5% acetonitrile, pH 7.5; 50 mm HEPES, pH 7.5. The copper content was monitored by atomic flame absorption spectroscopy (Varian AA-5). The protein was then concentrated using a modified ultrafree centrifugation system (Millipore, molecular weight cut-off 3500 Da). Final concentrations were 140 μm in copper and 220 μm in MBS2 with a copper stoichiometry of 0.7. The sample was sealed and stored at -80 °C XAS data were collected at the Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory (beamline 9-3, 3.0GeV, 50-100 mA). A bend rhodium-coated mirror positioned upstream of the fully tuned Si220 monochromator was used to cut off all energy above 12 keV. Cu+-MBS2 was analyzed in fluorescence mode using a Canberra 30 element array detector and was cooled down to 10 K using a liquid He flow cryostat (Oxford Instruments). The energy was calibrated by simultaneously measuring a copper metal foil and assigning the first inflection (26Ankudinov A.L. Ravel B. Rehr J.J. Conradson S.D. Phys. Rev. B. 1998; 58: 7565-7576Crossref Scopus (4107) Google Scholar) point of the copper edge to 8980.3 eV. For Cu+-MBS2, 10 scans were collected to k = 12.8 Å-1. Data reduction and analysis were performed using the EXAFSPAK computer suite (27George G.N. EXAFSPAK. Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Menlo Park, CA1995Google Scholar). Theoretical phase and amplitude functions were calculated using FEFF 8.2 (26Ankudinov A.L. Ravel B. Rehr J.J. Conradson S.D. Phys. Rev. B. 1998; 58: 7565-7576Crossref Scopus (4107) Google Scholar). The inspected raw data were averaged, and the background was subtracted and normalized. The EXAFS data were simulated by curve fitting in the OPT module of EXAFSPAK using a non-linear Marquadt algorithm, where the difference between the experimental and the calculated model is minimized. The following parameters were refined: ΔE0 (a small energy correction at k = 0, ranging from -5 to -20 eV), Ri (the distance between the central absorber and atom i), and σ2 (the Debye-Waller factor, defining the mean square deviation of Ri). A goodness-of-fit (Fw) parameter displayed at the end of each cycle was used to evaluate the merit of the fit. Fw is defined as Fw=∑k6(data-model)2k6(data)2(Eq. 1) Preparation and Expression of mMBS2-WNDP in Insect Cells—The generation of the plasmid encoding the full-length 4.4-kilobase WNDP cDNA (pFastBacDual-wild-type (wt-WNDP) and expression in Spodoptera frugiperda cells (Sf9) was previously described (28Tsivkovskii R. Eisses J.F. Kaplan J.H. Lutsenko S. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 976-983Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar). The WNDP variant of MBS2, where both cysteines within the metal binding motif GMTCQSC were substituted by alanines (mMBS2-WNDP), was generated using overlap PCR with the pFastBacDual-WNDP plasmid as a template. In the first amplification step, two fragments using forward primer (A) 5′-GCCTGGGAACCAGCAATGAAG-3′ and reverse (mutagenesis) primer 5′-CTGACAGCGGACTGGGCGGTCATGCCCTCCACCC-3′ and forward (mutagenesis) primer 5′-GCATGACCGCCCAGTCCGCTGTCAGCTCCATTGAAGG-3′ along with reverse primer (B) 5′-GTCGACTTAGGCTCCATCAGGAAGAGA-3′ were generated. The obtained fragments were then joined in the second PCR amplification step using primers A and B. The resulting product was subcloned into pCR-Blunt II TOPO vector (Invitrogen), and upon digestion with the restriction endonucleases ApaI and AflII, the fragment was inserted into the pFastBacDual-WNDP vector. The presence of the anticipated mutations was verified by automated DNA sequencing. The resulting construct was then incorporated into the bacmid using the Bac-to-Bac kit (Invitrogen) and previously described protocols (28Tsivkovskii R. Eisses J.F. Kaplan J.H. Lutsenko S. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 976-983Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar). After a 3-day infection with baculovirus, the Sf9 insect cells were harvested, and the total membrane fractions were prepared as previously described (28Tsivkovskii R. Eisses J.F. Kaplan J.H. Lutsenko S. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 976-983Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar, 29Hu Y.K. Kaplan J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 19185-19191Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar). The protein concentration in the total membrane fraction was determined by Lowry (30Lowry O.J. Rosebrough N.J. Farr A.L. Randall R.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1951; 193: 265-275Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Catalytic Phosphorylation of WNDP and mMBS2-WNDP from γ-[32P]ATP upon Incubation with Copper or Cu+-Atox1—Catalytic phosphorylation of WNDP and mMBS2-WNDP was analyzed using a previously described protocol (28Tsivkovskii R. Eisses J.F. Kaplan J.H. Lutsenko S. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 976-983Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar). Briefly, 50 μg of total membrane protein was resuspended in 200 μl of 100 μm Tris(2-carboxyethyl)phosphine hydrochloride, 20 mm bis-Tris propane, pH 7.0, 200 mm KCl, 5 mm MgCl2 and then incubated on ice with 250 μm copper chelator bathocuproine disulfonate (BCS, ICN Biomedicals) for 30 min to inhibit catalytic phosphorylation. The chelator was then removed by centrifugation, and the pellets were washed with 20 mm bis-Tris propane, pH 7.0, 200 mm KCl, 5 mm MgCl2 (phosphorylation buffer). The membranes were resuspended in phosphorylation buffer containing 100 μm ascorbate, 100 μm Tris(2-carboxyethyl)phosphine hydrochloride followed by the addition of increasing concentrations of CuCl2 or Cu+-Atox1. After a 10-min incubation at room temperature, γ-[32P]ATP (specific activity 25 mCi/μmol) was added to a final concentration of 1 μm, and the reaction was incubated on ice for 4 min. The reaction was stopped by the addition of 50 μl of ice-cold 1 mm NaH2PO4 in 50% trichloroacetic acid and then centrifuged for 10 min at 20,000 × g. The protein pellet was washed, resuspended in 40 μl of 5 mm Tris-PO4, pH 5.8, 6.7 m urea, 0.4 m dithiothreitol, 5% SDS and loaded on an acidic 7.5% polyacrylamide gel (31Sarkadi B. Enyedi A. Foldes-Papp Z. Gardos G. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 9552-9557Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). After electrophoresis, the gels were fixed in 10% acetic acid for 10 min and dried on blotting paper. The dried gels were exposed either to the Molecular Imaging screen CS (Bio-Rad) or at -80 °C to Kodak BioMax MS film. The intensity of the bands was quantified using a Bio-Rad Molecular Imager GS-525. The dried gels were rehydrated and stained with Coomassie Blue R250, and the amount of protein in the WNDP-related bands was determined by densitometry. The incorporation of 32P into WNDP was normalized to the WNDP protein levels. The Atox1-mediated Transfer of Copper to N-WNDP Selectively Protects Cysteines in MBS2 against Labeling with CPM—Previously, we demonstrated that Atox1 transferred copper to N-WNDP, stimulating the catalytic activity of WNDP (9Walker J.M. Tsivkovskii R. Lutsenko S. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 27953-27959Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar). To better understand the molecular details of this process, we sought to determine whether Cu+-Atox1 delivered copper to a specific site on N-WNDP. Our approach is outlined in Fig. 2A. Apo-N-WNDP was incubated either with Cu+-Atox1 to transfer one copper (9Walker J.M. Tsivkovskii R. Lutsenko S. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 27953-27959Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar) or with apoAtox1 as a control. After copper transfer and subsequent removal of Atox1, the cysteine residues in N-WNDP were labeled with the fluorescent reagent CPM. Copper binding to N-WNDP protects the metal-coordinating cysteines in N-WNDP from labeling with CPM (14Lutsenko S. Petrukhin K. Cooper M.J. Gilliam C.T. Kaplan J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 18939-18944Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (214) Google Scholar); therefore, the difference in the intensity of fluorescent labeling can be utilized for identification of the copper-bound MBS. To facilitate identification of the copper-bound MBS we also developed a protocol for limited proteolytic digestion of N-WNDP. MBSs in N-WNDP are thought to be compactly folded subdomains (12Jones C.E. Daly N.L. Cobine P.A. Craik D.J. Dameron C.T. J. Struct. Biol. 2003; 143: 209-218Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar, 13Gitschier J. Moffat B. Reilly D. Wood W.I. Fairbrother W.J. Nat. Struct. Biol. 1998; 5: 47-54Crossref PubMed Scopus (212) Google Scholar) connected by fairly long linkers (with the exception of MBS5 and MBS6, which are linked by a very short sequence). Therefore, it was expected that under mild conditions, the proteolytic digestion would occur within the linkers, leaving the MBSs intact. Indeed, treatment of labeled N-WNDP with low amounts of trypsin (1:2000 w/w) produced a series of the 8-16-kDa fragments that were stable to proteolysis for a period of about 3 h (the predicted mass for individual MBS without the linker sequence is ∼8 kDa). The tryptic fragments were separated by gel electrophoresis, and the fluorescence intensities of the peptide bands from the apo- and copper-bound N-WNDP were compared (Fig. 2). If Atox1 transfers copper to more than one site in N-WNDP, one would expect to see a partial decrease in fluorescence of several fragments. However, if Atox1 delivers copper to a preferential site, only one band should be protect

Transglutaminase (TGase) 2 is a ubiquitously expressed enzyme that modifies proteins by cross-linking or polyamination. An aberrant activity of TGase 2 has implicated its possible roles in a variety of diseases including age-related cataracts. However, the molecular mechanism by which TGase 2 is activated has not been elucidated. In this report, we showed that oxidative stress or UV irradiation elevates in situ TGase 2 activity. Neither the expression level nor the in vitro activity of TGase 2 appeared to correlate with the observed elevation of in situ TGase 2 activity. Screening a number of cell lines revealed that the level of TGase 2 activation depends on the cell type and also the environmental stress, suggesting that unrecognized cellular factor(s) may specifically regulate in situ TGase 2 activity. Concomitantly, we observed that human lens epithelial cells (HLE-B3) exhibited about 3-fold increase in in situ TGase 2 activity in response to the stresses. The activated TGase 2 catalyzed the formation of water-insoluble dimers or polymers of αB-crystallin, βB2-crystallin, and vimentin in HLE-B3 cells, providing evidence that TGase 2 may play a role in cataractogenesis. Thus, our findings indicate that in situ TGase 2 activity must be evaluated instead of in vitro activity to study the regulation mechanism and function of TGase 2 in biological and pathological processes. Transglutaminase (TGase) 2 is a ubiquitously expressed enzyme that modifies proteins by cross-linking or polyamination. An aberrant activity of TGase 2 has implicated its possible roles in a variety of diseases including age-related cataracts. However, the molecular mechanism by which TGase 2 is activated has not been elucidated. In this report, we showed that oxidative stress or UV irradiation elevates in situ TGase 2 activity. Neither the expression level nor the in vitro activity of TGase 2 appeared to correlate with the observed elevation of in situ TGase 2 activity. Screening a number of cell lines revealed that the level of TGase 2 activation depends on the cell type and also the environmental stress, suggesting that unrecognized cellular factor(s) may specifically regulate in situ TGase 2 activity. Concomitantly, we observed that human lens epithelial cells (HLE-B3) exhibited about 3-fold increase in in situ TGase 2 activity in response to the stresses. The activated TGase 2 catalyzed the formation of water-insoluble dimers or polymers of αB-crystallin, βB2-crystallin, and vimentin in HLE-B3 cells, providing evidence that TGase 2 may play a role in cataractogenesis. Thus, our findings indicate that in situ TGase 2 activity must be evaluated instead of in vitro activity to study the regulation mechanism and function of TGase 2 in biological and pathological processes. Transglutaminases (TGases) 1The abbreviations used are: TGase, transglutaminase; BP, biotinylated pentylamine; HRP, horseradish peroxidase; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline. are a family of enzymes that mediate the post-translational modification of proteins by catalyzing acyl transfer reaction between the γ-carboxamide group of glutamine residues and the ϵ-amino group of lysine residues or polyamines (1Lornad L. Graham R.M. Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2003; 4: 140-156Crossref PubMed Scopus (1213) Google Scholar). The calcium-dependent transamidation activity of TGases produces cross-linked protein polymers that are resistant to mechanical stress and proteolytic degradation (2Greenberg C.S. Birckbichler P.J. Rice R.H. FASEB J. 1991; 5: 3071-3077Crossref PubMed Scopus (935) Google Scholar). Thus, TGases are recognized to play critical roles in the formation of highly insoluble structures such as cornified cell envelope of the terminally differentiated keratinocyte (TGases 1 and 3, fibrin aggregates (coagulation factor XIII), and the post-copulatory plug of rodents (TGase 4) (3Kalinin A. Marekov L.N. Steinert P.M. J. Cell Sci. 2001; 117: 3069-3070Google Scholar, 4Takahashi N. Takahashi Y. Putnam F.W. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1986; 83: 8019-8023Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar, 5Mukherjee D.C. Agrawal A.K. Manjunath R. Mukherjee A.B. Science. 1983; 219: 989-991Crossref PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar). TGase 2 exhibits a similar protein structure and catalyzes transamidation reaction following a common mechanism as other TGases (6Liu S. Cerione R. Clardy J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2002; 99: 2743-2747Crossref PubMed Scopus (280) Google Scholar). However, TGase 2 is distinguished from other TGases by its widespread expression pattern, GTP hydrolyzing activity, and intracellular distribution. Although TGase 2 is mainly distributed in the cytosol, TGase 2 can translocate into the nucleus by binding to importin-α3 in response to an elevated intracellular calcium concentration (7Lesort M. Attanavanich K. Zhangm J. Johnson G.V. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 11991-11994Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (154) Google Scholar, 8Peng X. Zhang Y. Zhang H. Graner S. Williams J.F. Levitt M.L. Lokshin A. FEBS Lett. 1999; 446: 35-39Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar). A significant portion of TGase 2 is found in the plasma membrane or secreted into the extracellular matrix (9Nakaoka H. Perez D.M. Baek K.J. Das T. Husain A. Misono K. Im M.J. Graham R.M. Science. 1994; 264: 1593-1596Crossref PubMed Scopus (530) Google Scholar, 10Akimov S.S. Krylov D. Fleischman L.F. Belkin A.M. J. Cell Biol. 2000; 148: 825-838Crossref PubMed Scopus (421) Google Scholar). Because of its ability to cross-link proteins at distinct subcellular location, TGase 2 is implicated in a wide range of physiological processes, including apoptosis, cell adhesion, and differentiation (11Melino G. Piacentini M. FEBS Lett. 1988; 430: 59-63Crossref Scopus (170) Google Scholar, 12Sporn M.B. Roberts A.B. Cancer Res. 1983; 43: 3034-3040PubMed Google Scholar). However, the overexpression of TGase 2 did not change cell survival, indicating that the intracellular transamidation activity of TGase 2 is tightly regulated (13Gentile V. Thomazy V. Piacentini M. Fesus L. Davies P.J.A. J. Cell Biol. 1992; 119: 463-474Crossref PubMed Scopus (230) Google Scholar). The inappropriate cross-linking or polyamination of various proteins within cells may induce pathological consequences. Because TGase 2 catalyzes transamidation of the glutamine residues of amine acceptors, TGase 2 may contribute to the aggregation of huntingtin molecules with the expanded polyglutamine domain in Huntington's disease (14Green H. Cell. 1993; 74: 955-956Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (215) Google Scholar), the modification of the glutamine-rich gliadin peptides in celiac disease (15Anderson R.P. Degano P. Godkin A.J. Jewell D.P. Hill A.V. Nat. Med. 2000; 6: 337-342Crossref PubMed Scopus (488) Google Scholar), or the formation of crystallin dimers in age-related cataracts (16Lorand L. Hsu L.K.H. Siefring Jr., G.E. Rafferty N.S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1981; 78: 1356-1360Crossref PubMed Scopus (127) Google Scholar). Indeed, in the study of Huntington's disease the administration of cystamine, an inhibitor of TGase, prolonged the survival period of the mouse model (17Karpuj M.V. Becher M.W. Springer J.E. Chabas D. Youssef S. Pedotti R. Mitchell D. Steinman L. Nat. Med. 2002; 8: 143-149Crossref PubMed Scopus (348) Google Scholar). These findings suggest that an aberrant activation of TGase 2 is crucial for some pathologic processes. However, the molecular mechanism by which TGase 2 is activated has not been determined. In this report, we show that oxidative stress or UV irradiation can stimulate the in situ transamidation activity of TGase 2, and the elevated level of activity depends on the cell type and the nature of stress. Among the various cell lines examined, human lens epithelial cells (HLE-B3) were found to be most sensitive to the oxidative stress or UV irradiation. We present some evidence that the activation of intracellular TGase 2 may play a significant role in the development of human cataracts. Cell Culture and Transfection Experiments—Human cancer cell lines, A549 (lung), MCF7 (breast), and K562 (leukemia) cells, were maintained in RPMI 1640 medium containing 10% fetal bovine serum (Hyclone). NIH 3T3 (mouse fibroblast), HeLa (human cervical carcinoma), PC3M (human prostate carcinoma), and Du145 (human prostate carcinoma) cells were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum. HLE-B3 (human lens epithelial cell line) cells were grown in modified Eagle's medium containing 20% fetal bovine serum. Penicillin (100 units/ml), streptomycin sulfate (100 μg/ml), and glutamine (2 mm) were supplemented to all cell culture media. All of the cell lines were maintained in a humidified atmosphere with 5% CO2 at 37 °C. To investigate the effects of UV irradiation or oxidative stress, the cells (2× 106) were exposed to UVC (UVC-508, ULTRA-LUM Inc.; 100, 200, 300, and 400 J/m2, respectively) or treated with H2O2 (200, 400, 600, and 800 μm, respectively) for various times indicated and maintained in culture until analysis. Cystamine (Sigma) at 0.5 mm was added to culture media to inhibit the TGase 2 activity. Expression of TGase 2 in NIH 3T3 and MCF7 cells was carried out by transfection of pSG5 vector (Stratagene) containing full-length human TGase 2 or control vector using LipofectAMINE (Invitrogen) as previously described (18Jeon J.H. Kim C.W. Shin D.M. Kim K. Cho S.Y. Kwon J.C. Choi K.H. Kang H.S. Kim I.G. FEBS Lett. 2003; 534: 180-184Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar). In Vitro Transamidation Assays—In vitro TGase 2 activity was determined by measuring the incorporation of [14C] putrescine (PerkinElmer Life Sciences) into N,N′-dimethylcasein (Sigma) as previously described (19Jeon J.H. Cho S.Y. Kim C.W. Shin D.M. Kweon J.C. Choi K.H. Park S.C. Kim I.G. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2002; 294: 818-822Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar). In brief, the cell extracts were prepared by disrupting the cells with lysis buffer (50 mm Tris-Cl, pH 7.5, 50 mm KCl, 0.5 mm EDTA, 5 mm MgCl2, 0.5% Nonidet P-40, 5 mm dithiothreitol, and protease inhibitor mixture) followed by centrifugation (14,000 × g, 10 min at 4 °C). The cell extracts in 100 μg were incubated with substrate solution (1 mg of N,N′-dimethylcasein, 500 nCi of [14C] putrescine, 50 mm Tris acetate, pH 7.5, 10 mm CaCl2, 5 mm dithiothreitol, 150 mm NaCl, 0.5% Triton X-100, and protease inhibitor mixture) for 1 h at 37 °C. The reaction was stopped by adding 7.5% trichloroacetic acid, and the radioactivity bound to N,N′-dimethylcasein was measured using liquid scintillation counter (Packard Bioscience). The background radioactivity with bovine serum albumin was used as a control. In Situ Transamidation Assays—In situ TGase 2 activity was measured by three different assay methods (18Jeon J.H. Kim C.W. Shin D.M. Kim K. Cho S.Y. Kwon J.C. Choi K.H. Kang H.S. Kim I.G. FEBS Lett. 2003; 534: 180-184Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar, 19Jeon J.H. Cho S.Y. Kim C.W. Shin D.M. Kweon J.C. Choi K.H. Park S.C. Kim I.G. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2002; 294: 818-822Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar). The cells were labeled with 1 mm biotinylated pentylamine (BP; Pierce) for 1 h prior to harvesting, and the cell extracts were prepared by sonication, followed by centrifugation (14,000 × g, 10 min at 4 °C). For solid phase microtiter plate assay, cell extracts (0.2 mg/ml, 50 μl/well) in coating buffer (50 mm Tris-Cl, pH 7.5, 150 mm NaCl, 5 mm EGTA, 5 mm EDTA) were added to each well of a 96-well microtiter plate (Nunc). In situ TGase 2 activity was evaluated by determining the incorporated BP using horseradish peroxidase (HRP)-conjugated streptavidin (Zymed Laboratories Inc.), followed by the reaction with O-phenylenediamine dihydrochloride (Sigma). The assays were quantitated by measuring the absorbance at 490 nm on microplate spectrophotometer (Molecular Devices). Western blot analysis was performed by subjecting the cell extracts (20–30 μg) to SDS-PAGE using 12% gel, and the proteins were transferred to nitrocellulose membrane. The proteins incorporated with BP were probed with HRP-conjugated streptavidin, followed by chemiluminescence detection (Pierce). The protein level of TGase 2 or actin was assessed by probing with monoclonal antibodies specific for TGase 2 (20Jeon J.H. Choi K.H. Cho S.Y. Kim C.W. Shin D.M. Kweon J.C. Song K.Y. Park S.C. Kim I.G. EMBO J. 2003; 22: 5273-5282Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar) or actin (Santa Cruz), respectively. To perform cytochemical analysis, the cells were plated onto glass coverslips placed in a 6-well plate and cultured for 24 h. After exposing to UV at the dosage of 200 J/m2 or treating with H2O2 at 400 μm, the cells were maintained in culture for 12 h. The cells were labeled with 1 mm BP for 1 h prior to fixing with 4% formaldehyde in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) for 15 min, and the cellular membrane was permeabilized by treating with 0.1% Triton X-100 in PBS for 5 min at room temperature. The cells were incubated in 3% bovine serum albumin in PBS at room temperature for 30 min, and the extent of biotinylated polyamines incorporated into the cellular proteins was assessed using Texas Red-conjugated streptavidin (Jackson Laboratory). The cells were visualized and photographed with a confocal laser-scanning microscope (Bio-Rad). TGase 2-catalyzed Cross-linking of Lens Proteins—In situ TGase assay was carried out by exposing HLE-B3 cells to UV or by treating the cells with H2O2 and then separating the water-soluble and water-insoluble fractions as previously described (21Clement S. Velasco P.T. Murthy S.N. Wilson J.H. Lukas T.J. Goldman R.D. Lorand L. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 7604-7609Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar). In brief, the cell extracts were prepared by sonication in buffer H (50 mm Tris-Cl, pH 7.5, 20% glycerol, 5 mm dithiothreitol, and protease inhibitor mixture) and subsequent centrifugation (6,000 × g, 5 min at 4 °C). The extracts were further separated into water-soluble and water-insoluble fractions by centrifugation at 20,000 × g, 30 min at 4 °C. The pellets (water-insoluble fractions) were rinsed twice with buffer H and solubilized by incubating in buffer S (50 mm Tris-Cl, pH 6.8, 6 m urea, 2% SDS, 40 mm dithiothreitol, and protease inhibitor mixture) for 30 min at 37 °C. The proteins of each fraction were resolved in 8–12% SDS-PAGE and analyzed with antibodies specific for αB-crystallin (Calbiochem), βB2-crystallin (22Magabo K.S. Horwitz J. Piatigorsky J. Kantorow M. Invest. Ophthalmol. Vis. Sci. 2000; 41: 3056-3060PubMed Google Scholar), and vimentin (Santa Cruz), respectively. For cell-free assay of TGase 2-mediated cross-linking, HLE-B3 cells were homogenized by sonication in buffer H, followed by centrifugation (12,000 × g, 10 min at 4 °C). The cell extracts were incubated with buffer H containing various concentrations of CaCl2 for 2 h at 37 °C. Cystamine at 1 mm or GTP at 100, 200, and 400 μm was added to the reaction mixture. After reaction, the cell extracts were separated into water-soluble and water-insoluble fractions, and each fraction was analyzed by SDS-PAGE as described earlier. Protein Preparations—Vimentin was produced in BL21 cells as GST fusion protein (pGEX-4T-1; Amersham Bioscience) and purified by glutathione-Sepharose column chromatography according to the manufacturer's instructions. A baculovirus expression system (Pharmingen) was employed to produce recombinant TGase 2 according to the manufacturer's instructions. In brief, protein expression was induced by infecting Sf21 insect cells with baculovirus that contains a full-length human TGase 2 cDNA. Recombinant TGase 2 was purified using a nickel-nitrilotriacetic acid column according to the manufacturer's instructions (Qiagen), and TGase 2 activity was monitored in terms of [14C] putrescine incorporation (19Jeon J.H. Cho S.Y. Kim C.W. Shin D.M. Kweon J.C. Choi K.H. Park S.C. Kim I.G. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2002; 294: 818-822Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar). The purity of TGase 2 was assessed by SDS-PAGE analysis, followed by Coomassie Blue staining of protein bands. Both bovine α-crystallin and βBL-crystallin were purchased from Sigma, and βBH-crystallin was obtained from Stressgen. Kinetic Experiments—The wells of 96-well microtiter plate were coated with α-crystallin, βBH-crystallin, βBL-crystallin, and vimentin (30 μg/ml, 100 μl/well in PBS) for 2 h at room temperature and then overcoated with 200 μl of 5% bovine serum albumin with PBS for 2 h at room temperature. TGase 2 (0.5 μg/ml) was added to each well, which contained 2–100 μm of BP in 50 μl of reaction buffer (50 mm Tris-Cl, pH 7.5, 150 mm NaCl, 5 mm CaCl2, 0.5% Triton X-100, 0.5 mm EDTA, pH 8.0, 5 mm dithiothreitol, and protease inhibitor mixture), and the plates were incubated for 1 h at 37 °C. To study the effect of calcium or GTP on the kinetics of the above reaction, a predetermined amount of calcium or GTP was added to the reaction mixture to make the desired final concentrations. The progression of reaction was monitored by measuring the amount of incorporated BP using HRP-conjugated streptavidin. Correlation between in Situ TGase2 Activity and the Expression Level of TGase 2—Recently, conflicting results have been reported on the role of transamidation activity of TGase 2 in cellular apoptosis (23Oliverio S. Amendola A. Rodolfo C. Spinedi A. Piacentini M. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 34123-34128Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar, 24Antonyak M.A. Singh U.S. Lee D.A. Boehm J.E. Combs C. Zgola M.M. Page R.L. Cerione R.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 33582-33587Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar). To better understand the nature of the transamidation activity of TGase 2, we investigated whether the expression level of TGase 2 positively correlates with its in situ transamidation activity. NIH 3T3 and MCF7 cell lines that express TGase 2 at low levels were employed in the transient transfection study. The expression level of TGase 2 in both cell lines, as shown in Western blot analysis, appeared comparable (Fig. 1A, inset). When the in vitro transamidation activity of the cell lysates was measured by [14C]putrescine incorporation assay, NIH 3T3 cells exhibited a 5-fold increase of transamidation activity compared with the control, whereas MCF7 cells showed no significant changes (Fig. 1A, left panel). Subsequently, we examined the in situ activity of TGase 2 by incubating the respective cells with BP and by measuring the conjugated BP concentration in the cell extracts using well plate assay. Unexpectedly, the in situ transamidation activity was not detectable in both NIH 3T3 and MCF7 cells (Fig. 1A, right panel). These findings indicate that either in vitro or in situ transamidation activity of TGase 2 does not correlate with its expression level. We tested the possibility of artifact in the transfection study by treating MCF7 cells with retinoic acid to induce the expression of TGase 2. Incubation of MCF7 cells with retinoic acid for up to 48 h produced an increase in TGase 2 expression, but the increase correlated neither in vitro nor in situ transamidation activity (data not shown). To further verify that the lack of correlation between the in situ activity and the expression level of TGase 2 may also exist in other cell lines as well, we analyzed the expression and transamidation activity of TGase 2 in various cell lines (Fig. 1B). The in vitro activity of each cell appeared to be correlated with its TGase 2 expression level. By contrast, elevated in situ TGase 2 activity was detectable only in HeLa and Du145 cells but none of the other cell lines examined, irrespective of their TGase 2 expression levels, indicating that the intrinsic in situ TGase 2 activity varies depending on the type of cell (Fig. 1, B and C). To test whether the variance of the observed in situ TGase 2 activity depended upon the transport rate of BP, we measured intracellular BP concentration of each cell line (18Jeon J.H. Kim C.W. Shin D.M. Kim K. Cho S.Y. Kwon J.C. Choi K.H. Kang H.S. Kim I.G. FEBS Lett. 2003; 534: 180-184Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar). Nonetheless, we did not find any significant difference in intracellular BP concentration in the various types of cell examined (data not shown). Activation of Intracellular TGase 2 by Oxidative Stress or UV Irradiation—The apparent absence of in vitro TGase 2 activity in MCF7 cells suggests the existence of cellular factor(s) that may regulate TGase 2 activity. Because TGase 2 expression is up-regulated under hypoxic condition (25Wykoff C.C. Pugh C.W. Maxwell P.H. Harris A.L. Ratcliffe P.J. Oncogene. 2000; 19: 6297-6305Crossref PubMed Scopus (240) Google Scholar) or by chemotherapeutics that generate oxygen radical (26Mehta K. Int. J. Cancer. 1994; 58: 400-406Crossref PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar), we hypothesized that oxidative stress may affect this regulatory cellular factor(s). We evaluated the effect of oxidative stress on the in situ activity and in vitro activity as well as the expression level of TGase 2 in a variety of cells. When these cells were treated with 200 μm of H2O2 and then maintained in culture for 12 h prior to analysis, no significant change of in vitro TGase 2 activity was observed with all of the cell lines examined (Fig. 2A). However, K562 and HLE-B3 cells showed a 2–3-fold increase of in situ TGase 2 activity compared with that of the untreated cells. Under the experimental conditions employed in these studies, degradation or up-regulation of TGase 2 did not occur according to Western blot analysis. These observations suggest that the elevation of the in situ TGase 2 activity in K562 and HLE-B3 cells may be caused by activation of a latent enzyme. We also investigated the effect of another type of oxidative stress, UV irradiation, on the TGase 2 activity. The cell lines were irradiated with 100 J/m2 of UVC and then maintained in culture for 12 h. Among the cell lines examined, only HeLa and HLE-B3 cells produced a 2–3-fold increase in in situ TGase 2 activity compared with their controls (Fig. 2B). These results indicate that activation of TGase 2 varies depending on cell type and also the type of stress exerted on the cells. We verified with each cell line that the observed change in the in situ TGase 2 activity is not a result of cell viability in response to oxidative stresses (data not shown). Activation of TGase 2 in HLE-B3 Cells—HLE-B3 cells, immortalized human lens epithelial cells, exhibited a significant activation of intracellular TGase 2 in response to either H2O2 treatment or UV irradiation (Fig. 2). These results are of interest, particularly because of the facts that lens epithelial cells are known to differentiate into fiber cells that last throughout the human lifespan and that cross-linking of protein molecules resulting from environmental insult may lead to cataract formation. We examined the dose-response phenomenon between the stress level and the relative in situ TGase 2 activity in HLE-B3 cells. UV-irradiated or H2O2-treated HLE-B3 cells showed a 2–4-fold enhancement in the in situ TGase 2 activity depending on the dose of irradiation or H2O2 concentration (Fig. 3A). The maximum dose of irradiation or the highest concentration of H2O2 tested was 300 J/m2 and 600 μm, respectively. At a higher dose of UV irradiation or H2O2 concentration, the cells began to detach from the culture dish. Thus, the UV dosage of 200 J/m2 and the H2O2 concentration of 400 μm were employed, respectively, for the following experiments. The amount of proteins incorporated with BP catalyzed by TGase 2 increased gradually, reaching the maximum at 12 h and diminishing thereafter (Fig. 3B). This result was subsequently confirmed by Western blot experiment using HRP-conjugated streptavidin (Fig. 3C). Any degradation of TGase 2 during the experiment was not detectable according to Western blot analysis (Fig. 3, A and C). To validate these results further, we repeated the above experiments in the presence of cystamine as an inhibitor to TGase. Fig. 4A showed that the treatment of cystamine to the stressed HLE-B3 cells suppressed the elevated in situ TGase 2 activity to that of the control. This finding was corroborated by Western blot analysis using HRP-conjugated streptavidin (Fig. 4B) and also by cytochemical staining for in situ TGase 2 activity using Texas Red-conjugated streptavidin (Fig. 4C). Cross-linking of Lens Proteins by Activated TGase 2—We investigated the possibility that the TGase 2 activated by either UV irradiation or H2O2 treatment contributes to cross-linking lens proteins. HLE-B3 cells were exposed to UV or H2O2 and maintained in culture for 12 h in the absence or presence of cystamine. The cells were homogenized and separated into water-soluble and water-insoluble fractions. When the proteins were analyzed by Western blot methods using the antibodies specific for αB-crystallin, βB2-crystallin, and vimentin, respectively, new bands corresponding to respective dimeric or polymeric forms of αB-crystallin, βB2-crystallin, and vimentin appeared in the water-insoluble fractions. The apparent dimer or polymer bands were detectable neither in the water-soluble fraction nor in the fractions from cells treated with cystamine (Fig. 5A). Previous in vitro biochemical studies showed that the major structural lens proteins could be cross-linked by the addition of calcium into lens homogenate (16Lorand L. Hsu L.K.H. Siefring Jr., G.E. Rafferty N.S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1981; 78: 1356-1360Crossref PubMed Scopus (127) Google Scholar, 21Clement S. Velasco P.T. Murthy S.N. Wilson J.H. Lukas T.J. Goldman R.D. Lorand L. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 7604-7609Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar, 27Shridas P. Sharma Y. Balasubramanian D. FEBS Lett. 2001; 499: 245-250Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar, 28Berbers G.A.M. Bentlage H.C.M. Brans A.M.M. Bloemendal H. de Jong W.W. Eur. J. Biochem. 1983; 135: 315-320Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar). To compare our results obtained from in situ assay with those from in vitro cell-free assay, HLE-B3 cell homogenate was incubated in buffer containing either CaCl2 or cystamine. Based on Western blot analysis, the addition of CaCl2 to HLE-B3 cell homogenate produced cross-linking of αB-crystallin, βB2-crystallin, and vimentin (Fig. 5B). These results resemble the effects of oxidative stresses on HLE-B3 cells as described earlier and confirmed that oxidative stresses can promote the formation of water-insoluble polymers of lens proteins by activating intracellular TGase 2. Interestingly, shifting of monomeric forms of αB-crystallin and βB2-crystallin into water-insoluble fraction was noted (Fig. 5). These observations suggest that TGase 2 catalyzes some other types of modification such as polyamination or deamination (1Lornad L. Graham R.M. Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2003; 4: 140-156Crossref PubMed Scopus (1213) Google Scholar), leading to a change in their solubility in aqueous buffer. To understand the mechanism for cross-linking among lens proteins, we evaluated the kinetic parameters with which TGase 2 catalyzes the cross-linking reactions of each protein. As shown in Fig. 6A, Km values determined by BP incorporation assay for β-crystallins and vimentin were about 20 μm, whereas the Km value for α-crystallin was 129.9 μm, indicating that β-crystallins and vimentin have higher affinities for TGase 2 than α-crystallin. The degree of calcium dependence for transamidation reaction was evaluated with four lens proteins. The results in Fig. 6B revealed that βL-crystallin is most sensitive to calcium concentration, and α-crystallin is least sensitive protein among the four lens proteins (βL-crystallin > βH-crystallin > vimentin > α-crystallin, in order of decreasing calcium sensitivity). By contrast, GTP was equally effective in inhibiting the catalytic activity of TGase 2 in BP incorporation into four lens proteins (Fig. 6C). TGase 2 is an enzyme with dual function possessing both transamidation and GTP hydrolysis activities. The calcium-dependent transamidation activity of TGase 2 catalyzes ϵ-(γ-glutamyl)lysine cross-linking or the polyamination of proteins, which may induce conformational change. Thus, it has been proposed that TGase 2 catalyzes aggregation or polymerization of proteins in various human diseases such as Alzheimer's disease via up-regulation of its expression (29Kim S.Y. Grant P. Lee J.H. Pant H.C. Steinert P.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 30715-30721Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (207) Google Scholar). In this study, we found that intrinsic activity or activation of intracellular TGase 2 is cell type-dependent and that the activity does not correlate with the TGase 2 expression level. Therefore, in addition to Western blot analysis and the in vitro assay of TGase 2, the in situ activity of TGase 2 must be evaluated to establish the causal relationship between elevated expression of TGase 2 and phenotype changes. Previous reports have shown that intracellular TGase 2 is activated by calcium and inhibited by GTP (30Zhang J. Lesort M. Guttmann R.P. Johnson G.V.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 2288-2295Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (184) Google Scholar). However, the molecular mechanism that regulates the intracellular TGase 2 activity under physiological conditions has not been elucidated. We present, in this report, the results that demonstrate that in situ TGase 2 activity is increased when cells are exposed to oxidative stress or UV irradiation and that the level of activation appears to be dependent on cell type and the nature of stress. These results suggest that cellular factor(s) that specifically regulate TGase 2 activity in response to oxidative stress may exist. Based on this finding, it may be postulated that TGase 2 activation is involved in the mechanism and/or manifestation of the stress responses. Therefore, identification of the cellular factor that regulates TGase 2 activation and the nature of the proteins modified by TGase 2 under stress conditions would assist in understanding the intracellular functions of TGase 2. The results of this study also have important implications for the role of TGase 2 in age-related cataractogenesis. The epidemiological studies showed positive associations between the prevalence of cataracts and the level of UV exposure (31Cruickshanks K.J. KleinB E.K. Klein R. Am. J. Public Health. 1992; 82: 1658-1662Crossref PubMed Scopus (220) Google Scholar). Because antioxidant capacity is decreased during the aging process of lens (32Reddy V.N. Exp. Eye Res. 1990; 50: 771-778Crossref PubMed Scopus (225) Google Scholar), cataract formation may result from inadequate protection of lens proteins from oxidative stress caused by UV exposure. Earlier in vitro studies showed that α-crystallin, β-crystallin, and vimentin could be cross-linked by TGase 2 (16Lorand L. Hsu L.K.H. Siefring Jr., G.E. Rafferty N.S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1981; 78: 1356-1360Crossref PubMed Scopus (127) Google Scholar, 21Clement S. Velasco P.T. Murthy S.N. Wilson J.H. Lukas T.J. Goldman R.D. Lorand L. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 7604-7609Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar, 27Shridas P. Sharma Y. Balasubramanian D. FEBS Lett. 2001; 499: 245-250Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). In our experiment, UV irradiation on various types of cell produced no significant changes in the expression levels or in in vitro enzymatic activity of TGase 2. However, we showed that UV irradiation activates intracellular TGase 2 of HLE-B3 cells, which promotes the formation of water-insoluble, cross-linked αB-crystallin, βB2-crystallin, and vimentin, respectively. Thus, our results seem to provide a link between the epidemiological results on the role of UV exposure in age-related cataracts and the biochemical evidence that supports cross-linking of proteins as an underlying mechanism of age-related cataracts. It has been postulated that altered levels of ions including a marked increase in calcium may be one of major changes associated with cataractous lens (33Kuck J.F.R. Exp. Eye Res. 1990; 50: 659-664Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). However, no significant difference in the GTP level was noted between clear and cataractous lens, although GTP level seemed slightly depressed with advancing age (34Deussen A. Pau H. Exp. Eye Res. 1989; 48: 37-47Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar). Our results show that GTP effectively inhibits the TGase-catalyzed protein cross-linking reaction, which is calcium-dependent. The activation of intracellular TGase 2 may require other cellular changes resulting from oxidative stresses accompanying an increase in calcium concentration. α-Crystallin, a major component of lens fiber and epithelial cells, belongs to the small heat shock protein family that prevent denaturation and aggregation of proteins in cells that are stressed (35Wistow G. FEBS Lett. 1985; 181: 1-6Crossref PubMed Scopus (122) Google Scholar). Knockout mice lacking α-crystallin develop lens opacities (36Brady J.P. Garland D. Duglas-Tabor Y. Robison Jr., W.G. Groome A. Wawrousek E.F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 884-889Crossref PubMed Scopus (300) Google Scholar), indicating that functional α-crystallin is essential for maintaining transparency of lens. Because αB-crystallin dimer may lose its chaperone-like function and be sequestered into the water-insoluble fraction (27Shridas P. Sharma Y. Balasubramanian D. FEBS Lett. 2001; 499: 245-250Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar), TGase 2-catalyzed dimerization of α-crystallin may be a critical step to initiate protein aggregation. Taken together, the present study provides the first evidence that TGase 2 may play an important role in age-related cataract formation. Furthermore, αB-crystallin expression is reported to be elevated in the neurons of degenerative diseases such as Alexander's disease (37Iwaki T. Kume-Iwaki A. Liem R.K. Goldman J.E. Cell. 1989; 57: 71-78Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (489) Google Scholar), which is related to protein aggregation. In this context, activation of intracellular TGase 2 in response to oxidative stress is an important issue that merits further investigation with various cell types. We thank Dr. Y. D. Kim for critical comments on the manuscript and Dr. Joseph Horwitz for kindly providing polyclonal antibody against bovine βB2-crystallin.

Meiotic cell cycle progression during vertebrate oocyte maturation requires the correct temporal translation of maternal mRNAs encoding key regulatory proteins. The mechanism by which specific mRNAs are temporally activated is unknown, although both cytoplasmic polyadenylation elements (CPE) within the 3′-untranslated region (3′-UTR) of mRNAs and the CPE-binding protein (CPEB) have been implicated. We report that in progesterone-stimulated Xenopus oocytes, the early cytoplasmic polyadenylation and translational activation of multiple maternal mRNAs occur in a CPE- and CPEB-independent manner. We demonstrate that polyadenylation response elements, originally identified in the 3′-UTR of the mRNA encoding the Mos proto-oncogene, direct CPE- and CPEB-independent polyadenylation of an early class of Xenopus maternal mRNAs. Our findings refute the hypothesis that CPE sequences alone account for the range of temporal inductions of maternal mRNAs observed during Xenopus oocyte maturation. Rather, our data indicate that the sequential action of distinct 3′-UTR-directed translational control mechanisms coordinates the complex temporal patterns and extent of protein synthesis during vertebrate meiotic cell cycle progression. Meiotic cell cycle progression during vertebrate oocyte maturation requires the correct temporal translation of maternal mRNAs encoding key regulatory proteins. The mechanism by which specific mRNAs are temporally activated is unknown, although both cytoplasmic polyadenylation elements (CPE) within the 3′-untranslated region (3′-UTR) of mRNAs and the CPE-binding protein (CPEB) have been implicated. We report that in progesterone-stimulated Xenopus oocytes, the early cytoplasmic polyadenylation and translational activation of multiple maternal mRNAs occur in a CPE- and CPEB-independent manner. We demonstrate that polyadenylation response elements, originally identified in the 3′-UTR of the mRNA encoding the Mos proto-oncogene, direct CPE- and CPEB-independent polyadenylation of an early class of Xenopus maternal mRNAs. Our findings refute the hypothesis that CPE sequences alone account for the range of temporal inductions of maternal mRNAs observed during Xenopus oocyte maturation. Rather, our data indicate that the sequential action of distinct 3′-UTR-directed translational control mechanisms coordinates the complex temporal patterns and extent of protein synthesis during vertebrate meiotic cell cycle progression. Early developmental cell fate decisions are regulated through the translational activation of maternally derived mRNAs. Cell. 1997; 8: 1633-1648Crossref PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar, 25de Moor C.H. Richter J.D. Mol. Cell Biol. 1997; 17: 6419-6426Crossref PubMed Scopus (131) Google Scholar, 27Mendez R. Daniel D.L.J. Wickens M. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1997; 8: 1633-1648Crossref PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar, 25de Moor C.H. Richter J.D. Mol. A generalized understanding of the molecular mechanisms governing the temporal control of maternal mRNA translational activation has been confounded by a number of inconsistencies in assignment of CPE-containing mRNAs to particular classes, as well as differences in temporal regulation within class groups. Furthermore, the conversion of CPEB from a translational repressor to a translational activator appears to occur too late to regulate early mRNA cytoplasmic polyadenylation and translational activation. CPEB conversion involves both Aurora A/Eg2- and cdc2-dependent phosphorylation (28Mendez R. Barnard D. Richter J.D. EMBO J. 2002; 21: 1833-1844Crossref PubMed Scopus (145) Google Scholar, 29Mendez R. Hake L.E. Andresson T. Littlepage L.E. Ruderman J.V. Richter J.D. Nature. 2000; 404: 302-307Crossref PubMed Scopus (294) Google Scholar). EMBO J. 2002; 21: 2798-2806Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar), and although initial studies suggested Aurora A/Eg2 activation occurred early during maturation (29Mendez R. Hake L.E. Andresson T. Littlepage L.E. Ruderman J.V. Richter J.D. Nature. 2000; 404: 302-307Crossref PubMed Scopus (294) Google Scholar, 31Andrèsson T. Ruderman J.V. Chem. 2003; 278: 21439-21449Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar, 33Frank-Vaillant M. Haccard O. Thibier C. Ozon R. Arlot-Bonnemains Y. Prigent C. Jessus C. J. Cell Sci. 2000; 113: 1127-1138Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 34Castro A. Mandart E. Lorca T. Galas S. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 2236-2241Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar) have concluded that Eg2 activation is temporally late and perhaps dependent on prior cdc2 activation. The recent identification of a CPE- and CPEB-independent regulatory mechanism that controls the early translational activation of the Mos mRNA (30Charlesworth A. Ridge J.A. King L.A. MacNicol M.C. MacNicol A.M. EMBO J. 2002; 21: 2798-2806Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar) suggests that CPE- and CPEB-independent regulatory mechanisms may be more generally utilized to generate the range of temporal profiles of maternal mRNA translational activation observed during meiotic cell cycle progression. The limited number of endogenous mRNAs or reporter RNAs that have been studied simultaneously has hampered elucidation of the mechanisms controlling the timing of maternal mRNA translational activation. Moreover, many of the 3′-UTR reporter constructs used previously were not full length thus compromising the generality of the conclusions that could be drawn. To circumvent these prior problems, we have utilized RNA ligation-coupled PCR (35Rassa J.C. Wilson G.M. Brewer G.A. Parks G.D. Virology. 2000; 274: 438-449Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar) from the same oocyte samples to investigate the temporal kinetics of cytoplasmic polyadenylation of multiple endogenous mRNAs during oocyte meiotic maturation. We report that contrary to current dogma, CPE- and CPEB-dependent mechanisms do not control temporally early maternal mRNA polyadenylation and translational activation during Xenopus oocyte maturation. We define a new class of Xenopus maternal mRNAs, which undergo temporally early CPE- and CPEB-independent cytoplasmic polyadenylation and translational activation. We demonstrate that polyadenylation response elements (PREs) present in the 3′-UTRs of early class mRNAs function to direct temporally early cytoplasmic polyadenylation and translational activation. By contrast, the cytoplasmic polyadenylation of CPE- and CPEB-dependent mRNAs is a temporally late event. Our findings suggest that the sequential action of distinct 3′-UTR-directed translational control mechanisms coordinates the complex temporal patterns and extent of protein synthesis during vertebrate meiotic cell cycle progression. DNA Constructs—The 211-nt D7 3′-UTR, the 146-nt G10 3′-UTR, and the 71-nt histone-like B4 3′-UTR were isolated from immature Xenopus oocytes by RT-PCR using primers containing 5′ XbaI sites and 3′ SalI sites and cloned into pGEM GST (9Charlesworth A. Welk J. MacNicol A. Dev. Biol. 2000; 227: 706-719Crossref PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar) for polyadenylation and translation studies, or into pGEM4Z (Promega) for RNA EMSAs. It should be noted that the D7 3′-UTR was larger than predicted and was found to encode an additional 21 nucleotides of 3′ sequence not present in the GenBank™ entry, including a canonical AAUAAA polyadenylation hexanucleotide. The histone-like B4 CPE was changed from uuuuuaau to uuuuGGau; the D7 CPEs were changed from uuuuuuaa, uuuuaaca, uuuuuaca, and uuuuuau to uuuuuGGa, uuuGGaca, uuuuGGca, and uuuuGGu; and the G10 CPEs were changed from uuuuaau and uuuuuuau to uuuGGau and uuuuuGGu using QuikChange (Stratagene). The D7 UTR was truncated using standard PCR mutagenesis to remove the two 5′-most CPEs, while leaving the PRE intact (see Fig. 7A for PRE boundary). The PRE in the D7 UTR was deleted by using QuikChange. The B4, D7, and G10 3′-UTR constructs were linearized with SalI prior to in vitro transcription. Cell Biol. 2002; 156: 75-85Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar). Oocytes were induced to mature with 2 μg/ml progesterone, and pools of 5 or 6 oocytes were taken at the indicated times. Where synthetic RNA constructs were injected, collection of immature controls was performed in concert with time-matched progesterone-stimulated samples. Germinal vesicle breakdown (GVBD) was used as an indicator of maturation and assessed by the presence of a white spot on the animal pole. Where indicated, oocytes were segregated at the time when 50% of the oocyte population had reached GVBD (GVBD50) based on whether they had (+) or had not (-) completed GVBD. EMBO J. 2002; 21: 2798-2806Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). Total RNA was isolated using RNA STAT-60 (Tel-Test) (3Howard E.L. Charlesworth A. Welk J. MacNicol A.M. Mol. Cell Biol. 1999; 19: 1990-1999Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar). Virology. 2000; 274: 438-449Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). 1 μl of this cDNA preparation was used in each 50-μl PCR using Platinum Taq (Invitrogen), according to the manufacturer's directions. The specific primers used were designed to be 70–110 nucleotides from the poly(A) addition site according to sequence information available in GenBank™, and the accession numbers are as follows: X13855 (B4 mRNA for histone H1-like protein); XLD7 (maternal mRNA D7); Z17206 (Aurora A/Eg2); U24491 (FGF receptor 1); XLG10 (maternal G10 mRNA); X13311 (p39mos); J03166 (cyclin B1); AJ304991 (cyclin B4); U13962 (Xe-Wee1A); X53745 (cyclin A1); and M24769 (cytoskeletal actin type 5).
